docs.lead_paragraph: LACONIA, N.H., - Besides delivering his usual message on drug companies and universal health care, former Senator John Edwards proved agile at fielding questions tossed out by New Hampshire voters today.

headline.main: Edwards Goes Courting in New Hampshire

docs.abstract: What's on voters' minds? The sky - the moon, actually - is the limit.
docs.snippet: What's on voters' minds? The sky - the moon, actually - is the limit.

docs.lead_paragraph: Laura Bush, whose recent outspoken support for Burmese democracy advocates has raised her profile, made a rare appearance on Fox News Sunday. Also on the talk shows were Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, soon to be the nation's first Indian-American governor; presidential hopefuls including Senators John McCain and Chris Dodd and the former Arkansas governor Mike Huckabee; and others, for discussions that ranged from Iran's nuclear program to abortion and the nomination of Michael B. Mukasey as attorney general.

headline.main: A Chat With the First Lady

docs.abstract: Laura Bush and Governor-elect Bobby Jindal of Louisiana on Fox News Sunday.
docs.snippet: Laura Bush and Governor-elect Bobby Jindal of Louisiana on Fox News Sunday.

docs.lead_paragraph: After the 2004 election, evangelical Christians looked like one of the most powerful and cohesive voting blocs in America. Three years later their leadership is split along generational and theological lines. How did it all come apart?

headline.seo: Evangelical Movement - Religion and Politics - Presidential Election of 2008 - Christians and Christianity - Voting and Voters

docs.lead_paragraph: Bloggers have been lighting up the Media Matters site all last night and all of today with their take on how the federal/state/local government responses to the California wildfires compare to those during the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina in 2005.
docs.abstract: Why has the government response to the California wildfires been better than that to Hurricane Katrina? Bloggers discuss.
docs.snippet: Why has the government response to the California wildfires been better than that to Hurricane Katrina? Bloggers discuss.

docs.lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives yesterday again approved a bill to expand the State Children's Health Insurance Program by a substantial margin -- 265 to 142 -- but that was less than the two-thirds needed to override another promised veto by President Bush.
docs.abstract: The House of Representatives yesterday again approved a bill to expand the State Children's Health Insurance Program by a substantial margin - 265 to 142 - but that was less than the two-thirds needed to override another promised veto by President Bush. The Democrats overwhelmingly supported the bill; only one Democrat voted against it. The [...]

docs.lead_paragraph: Employers now have the authority to automatically enroll employees in 401(k) retirement plans. But the real problems lie with small businesses that offer no plans at all.

headline.main: Small Business Retirement Time Bomb Ticks On

docs.snippet: Employers now have the authority to automatically enroll employees in 401(k) retirement plans. But the real problems lie with small businesses that offer no plans at all.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is common knowledge on Madison Avenue that branded entertainment is becoming increasingly popular on television as marketers -- worried about how easy it is for viewers to avoid commercials -­ arrange for their products to be woven into the plots of shows. Allstate Insurance is trying a different angle tonight: You could call it cause-related entertainment, integrating an issue into an episode of a scripted television series.
docs.abstract: Tonight, viewers of "Friday Night Lights" will not see a poster about safe driving bearing an Allstate logo on a wall of the high school in which the series takes place. Nor will there be an actor playing the local Allstate agent reassuring teenagers that they're "in good hands" if they drive safely. Instead, the issue will be brought up through scenes in which a principal cast member, Julie Taylor (portrayed by Aimee Teegarden) is being taught to drive by her father, the football coach Eric Taylor (Kyle Chandler), and her mother, Tami Taylor (Connie Britton).
